De Meyer’s collection restricts itself to editions, scholarly articles, and translations. The bibliography in John Maier’s Gilgamesh: A Reader goes much further and includes popular versions as well as various literary adaptations

title: Henrietta McCall’s “Rediscovery and Aftermath

focuses on the popular reception, principally in England. McCall mentions a few French contributions—notably the paintings of Delacroix (La mort de Sardanapale, 1827) and Dégas (Sémiramis construisant Babylone, 1860)—but makes the point that the French publications with their exquisite plates—for example, the fivevolume Monument de Ninive (1849–50)—were, unlike the books in England, prohibitively expensive and inaccessible to the general public
